This method of undermining a person's argument is called ad hominem. I've seen it be used against dozens of people, including politicians that focus on others instead of themselves. It's a logical fallacy that you have to call out to hopefully break. When I mean hopefully, I mean that you have to show to the audience that just because someone acts/talks in this way does not mean that whatever points or thoughts they tell are valid. The same is for perfect, flawless looking people. Just because they are skinny and sound as suave as a slick blade does not mean they have well constructed or valid points. Watch the words, not the speaker.

I know how you feel Rich. I'm turning 35 this year. I'm still young but I have alot of experience when it comes to PC. I have been building and using PC for over quarter century now. Suffice it to say, I have seen a lot of things in the PC. The thing that what bothers me most about PC is not because of console peasantry quotes that are floating around. Those are minor misinformation's which can be quickly debunk. What bothers me is the open platform that we enjoy slowly becoming like closed platform. For instance the sheer exclusivity of one gaming API, Direct X. Back in the day, we had multiple API that people used. This gave us more option beyond Microsoft platform. Also how Nvidia is pushing proprietary technologies with bogus "certification" fee. Along with how Intel implemented hardware level DRM to access key features which was available to us openly before. And I haven't got into digital distributions is transitioning to exclusivity deals. When I mention this to younger people, they don't understand how  much it can pose danger to open platform because most of them grew into this business model.

So this is what you call an "ad hominem".  It's a type of logical fallacy, or lapse in logical thinking, such as but not limited to contradicting itself, or being about something not related to the topic.  An Adhominem fallacy is when you attack the person and not their argument, this can be their age, weight, personality type, etc.  In a formal debate, the first person to resort to an ad hominem is labeled the loser.
